III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
Description qualifications
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Allegation 1:
Former Staff 3 spoke with youth while youth were on their home
passes.
Allegation 2:
Former Staff 4 was known to have sexual relationships with
Former Youth A and would talk sexually to youth. Former Staff 4
was in a relationship with Former Youth C and Former Youth D.
Investigation Allegation 1:
Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 6/23/2025
and did not provide additional information.
Former Youth A was interviewed over the phone on
6/27/2025. Former Youth A stated the allegation occurred
regarding Former Staff 3, when she was placed at Vista Maria
between 9/2018 – 6/2019. Former Youth A stated she only heard
of rumors of Former Staff 3 calling youth while youth were on a
home pass. She could not recall any names of the former youth
this happened to and stated she never had any interactions with
Former Staff 3.
Former Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 6/27/2025.
Former Staff 3 stated he worked at Vista Maria from 2/2017 –
2/2021 as a youth specialist. He reported he has never spoken to
a youth while on a home pass. He stated he quit working at Vista
Maria due to the number of allegations that named him as a
perpetrator, and they weren’t true. He stated he has children, and
he did not want the allegations to affect them. He stated
sometimes the youth would say, “[Former Staff 3] is my boyfriend”.
He did not feel like upper management was interested in
protecting staff from complaints.
2

Staff 6 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/8/2025.
Staff 6 has no knowledge and has not heard of Former Staff 3
talking to youth while youth were on a home pass.
HR Manager was interviewed over the phone on 6/13/2025.
HR Manager stated she has no knowledge and has not heard of
Former Staff 3 speaking to youth while youth were on a home
pass.
Former Youth C was interviewed over the phone on
8/22/2025. Former Youth C stated she was placed at Vista Maria
a total of five times and she was placed during 2018-2019. She
stated she does not recall having any concerns with Former Staff
3. He did work on her unit, but he was never inappropriate with
her. She has only heard rumors of Former Staff 3 contacting youth
on home passes but this was several years ago. She does not
recall who she heard the rumors from.
Staff 7 was interviewed over the phone on 8/22/2025. She did
not recall who Former Staff 3 was.
A phone call attempt was made to Former Youth’s D last
known number on 8/21/2025, however, that number is
disconnected. A MiSACWIS search did not provide additional
contact information for Former Youth D.
A voicemail was left for Former Staff 2 on 6/9/2025 and
6/27/2025. No return call was received.
Former Staff 5 was contacted on 6/27/2025 and a voicemail
message was left. No return call was received.
A voicemail was left for Former Staff 1 on 6/9/2025 and
6/27/2025. No return call was received.
Documentation Reviewed:
• Staff and Client Interaction Policy:
o All Vista Maria staff should conduct themselves in a
professional and appropriate manner when interacting with
the clients in our care. Employees are expected to establish
good working relationships to foster mutual trust with
clients.
o Guidelines for staff and client interaction:
o Never give out personal telephone numbers, address, or
social media profile information to clients.
3

o Do not socialize with current or former clients except during
Vista Maria-sponsored activities.
• Staff members should never present themselves in a
manner that could be construed as flirtatious or sexual in
nature to clients.
• Former Staff 3 personnel file: 1 discipline record not related
to the allegation. No grievances or incident reports related
to the allegation.
Allegation 2:
Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 6/23/2025
and did not provide additional information.
Former Youth A was interviewed over the phone on
6/27/2025. Former Youth A stated the allegation regarding Former
Staff 4, occurred when she was placed at Vista Maria between
9/2018 – 6/2019. Former Youth A stated she only heard rumors of
Former Staff 4 having a sexual relationship with Former Youth C
and Former Youth D. Former Youth A stated she never had any
interaction with Former Staff 4.
Former Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 6/27/2025.
Former Staff 3 stated he has never witnessed or heard of Former
Staff 4 being in a sexual relationship with any youth. He stated
Former Staff 4 was a supervisor and mostly stayed behind the
desk. He stated he could not recall how Former Staff 4 interacted
with Former Youth A as Former Staff 4 was a floater and he
mostly worked on Rose Hall while Former Staff 3 worked on
Donna Maria.
Former Staff 4 was interviewed over the phone on 6/27/2025.
Former Staff 4 stated he worked at Vista Maria from 2017 to 2020
as a supervisor. He stated he never had any sexual relationships
with any youth. He reported most of the time he stayed behind the
desk and did not have much interaction with youth. He reported he
was never alone with any youth, and he never went to their
bedroom or shower areas.
Staff 6 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/8/2025.
Staff 6 reported she has no knowledge of the allegation regarding
Former Staff 4. She has only heard rumors of Former Staff 4
wanting to date other staff. Staff 6 did not work the same shift as
Former Staff 4 and had no additional information to provide.
4

HR Manager was interviewed over the phone on 6/13/2025.
HR Manager stated she has no knowledge of the allegation
regarding Former Staff 4 having a sexual relationship with Former
Youth C and Former Youth D.
Former Youth C was interviewed over the phone on
8/22/2025. Former Youth C stated the only interaction she had
with Former Staff 4 was when they walked past one another in the
school hallway and his whole body bumped into her. She stated
that nothing was said before, during or after the interaction. She
did not recall a specific month and date. She reported that no
other staff or youth were around. She denied having a sexual
relationship with Former Staff 4 or any staff at Vista Maria.
Staff 7 was interviewed over the phone on 8/22/2025. She did
not recall who Former Staff 4 was.
A phone call attempt was made to Former Youth’s D last
known number on 8/21/2025, however, that number is
disconnected. A MiSACWIS search did not provide additional
contact information for Former Youth D.
A voicemail was left for Former Staff 2 on 6/9/2025 and
6/27/2025. No return call was received.
Former Staff 5 was contacted on 6/27/2025 and a voicemail
message was left. No return call was received.
A voicemail was left for Former Staff 1 on 6/9/2025 and
6/27/2025. No return call was received.
Documentation Reviewed:
• Former Youth’s D MiSACWIS search for contact
information on 8/21/2025, no new information was found.
• Staff and Client Interaction Policy:
o All Vista Maria staff should conduct themselves in a
professional and appropriate manner when interacting with
the clients in our care. Employees are expected to establish
good working relationships to foster mutual trust with
clients.
o Guidelines for staff and client interaction:
• Never give out personal telephone numbers,
address, or social media profile information to
clients.
• Do not socialize with current or former clients except
during Vista Maria-sponsored activities.
5

• Staff members should never present themselves in a
manner that could be construed as flirtatious or
sexual in nature to clients.
o Former Staff 4 personnel file: the file did not contain any
disciplinary record, incident reports or grievances related to
the allegation.
Analysis Allegation 1:
The agency is found in compliance as there was not enough
evidence to support a rule violation of Former Staff 3 speaking to
youth while on a home pass.
Allegation 2:
The agency is found in compliance as there was not enough
evidence to support a rule violation of Former Staff 4 having
sexual relationships with Former Youth A and talking to youth
sexually. There was not enough evidence to support a rule
violation of Former Staff 4 being in a relationship with Former
Youth C and Former Youth D.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4123. Education
Section (2) Provision shall be made for an appropriate education program
Description in accordance with 1976 PA 451, MCL 380.1 to 380.1853. Each
resident of school age shall be enrolled not later than 5 school
days after admission and continuously thereafter.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Former Youth B did not attend school.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 6/23/2025
and did not provide additional information.
Former Youth A was interviewed over the phone on
6/27/2025. Former Youth A stated this allegation occurred when
she was placed at Vista Maria between 9/2018 – 6/2019. Former
Youth A stated Former Youth B never went to school the entire
time of Former Youth B’s placement at Vista Maria which was
around 4-5 months.
Staff 6 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/8/2025.
Staff 6 reported she mainly supervised the one-on-one
observation for Former Youth B during her stay at Vista Maria.
Staff 6 reported that for her shift, she would sit outside of Former
Youth B’s door due to Former Youth B being on 100 observation.
100 observation means a youth is on one-to-one supervision.
Former Youth B consistently tried to commit suicide, and that is
why she had to be on 100 observation. Staff 6 could not recall if
6

Former Youth B went to school or not due to her working in the
afternoons.
HR Manager was interviewed over the phone on 6/13/2025.
HR Manager stated Former Youth B was placed at Vista Maria
Community Living program from 11/2018 – 9/2018, Shepard Hall
from 9/2018 – 11/2018 and Donna Maria from 11/2018- 3/2019.
HR Manager stated Former Youth B was on a 100 observation.
The protocol for the observation is for staff to sit outside of a
youth’s bedroom door and to always monitor the youth. HR
Manager reported Former Youth B would attend school but would
make suicidal threats or try to self-harm, and she would need to
go back on 100 observation. HR Manager reported the school did
send schoolwork over for Former Youth B to complete.
Staff 7 was interviewed over the phone 8/22/2025. Staff 7
reported she has been working at Vista Maria since 2013 and has
been in multiple roles. During Former Youth’s B placement, Staff 7
was the youth and family specialist, and she specifically worked
with Former Youth B. Former Youth B did have to spend the
majority of her time on 100 observation due to Former Youth B’s
depression. Staff 7 stated Former Youth B would come out of her
room to attend court or school. Staff 7 stated Former Youth B
attended school multiple times, however she would try to climb out
of the window or leave the school during lunchtime. Therefore, it
was not always safe for Former Youth B to be at school.
A voicemail was left for Former Staff 2 on 6/9/2025 and
6/27/2025. No return call was received.
Former Staff 5 was contacted on 6/27/2025 and a voicemail
message was left. No return call was received.
A voicemail was left for Former Staff 1 on 6/9/2025 and
6/27/2025. No return call was received.
Please note: Former Youth B passed away.
Documentation Reviewed:
• Client Observation Policy: The client will not attend school
while on observation status as a suicide risk or truancy
watch.
• Former Youth’s B file: Former Youth B’s Report card dated
for 1/24/2019 was reviewed confirming she attended
school. Updated Service Plan dated 3/17/2019: Youth B
started at a local school district on 11/19/2018.
7

• MiSACWIS Review: This indicated Youth B was enrolled at
a local school district on 11/13/2018 and was placed at
Vista Maria on 11/9/2018.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff interviews and
client observation policy, Former Youth B did attend school when
not on observation status and at risk of suicide. She was enrolled
at a local school district within 5 days of placement.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126. Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth would self-harm with contraband.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 6/23/2025
and did not provide additional information.
Former Youth A was interviewed over the phone on
6/27/2025. Former Youth A stated the allegation occurred when
she was placed at Vista Maria between 9/2018 – 6/2019. She
stated youth would steal objects from school and harm
themselves at Vista Maria. Former Youth A did not recall a
specific incident, staff or youth. She stated that contraband is not
allowed at Vista Maria. Former Youth A reported youth were
supposed to be patted down once re-entering the building, but
staff rarely did this.
Staff 6 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/8/2025.
Staff 6 has no knowledge of any youth self-harming with
contraband. Staff 6 stated that youth are not patted down but staff
do use a metal detector wand.
HR Manager was interviewed over the phone on 6/13/2025.
HR Manager stated youth would bring contraband from school or
when they went on home passes. Youth are inspected once back
at Vista Maria.
Former Youth C was interviewed over the phone on
8/22/2025. Former Youth C stated the contraband youth snuck in
were mostly vape pens. She does not recall youth self-harming
with other contraband.
8

Staff 7 was interviewed over the phone on 8/22/2025. Staff 7
reported the protocol for when a youth re-enters campus is for
youth to write down everything that they have. Staff 7 stated an
example is a wired bra that may have been purchased on a home
visit, which is not allowed. Staff 7 stated youth have tried to sneak
in vape pens, pencils, pens, cigarettes, shoes string and wired
headphones. Staff 7 stated staff use a metal detector wand,
however, they are not allowed to physically touch the youth. Staff
7 stated the youth would hide contraband in their hair or private
parts, and staff were not aware. Staff 7 reported she could not
recall youth harming themselves with contraband.
A phone call attempt was made to Former Youth’s D last
known number on 8/21/2025, however, that number is
disconnected. A MiSACWIS search did not provide additional
contact information for Former Youth D.
A voicemail was left for Former Staff 2 on 6/9/2025 and
6/27/2025. No return call was received.
Former Staff 5 was contacted on 6/27/2025 and a voicemail
message was left. No return call was received.
A voicemail was left for Former Staff 1 on 6/9/2025 and
6/27/2025. No return call was received.
Documents Review:
• School Check In And Out Policy:
o All clients are required to be checked in before and after
school hours and after any off campus outings (field trip).
The check in and out procedure has been put in place to
ensure the safety of all clients, teachers, and staff.
o Check In Procedure:
o 1. Each client must empty all pockets, take off shoes, and
lift bottom bra band outward.
o 2. Each client must stay in sight of a staff until check in
procedure is complete.
o Check Out – All clients leaving the unit must allow staff to
check books, folders. All clients must perform procedure
used to check in before exiting unit.
o Check In to Unit From School – All clients are to perform
check in procedures before entering bedrooms or any area
besides foyer. Each student must show staff inside of
shoes, all pockets must be emptied; staff must inspect all
bags and purses.
9

o Consequences for Vista Maria Clients – will range from a
plan of action to in unit schooling.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as there is insufficient
evidence found that youth were harming themselves with
contraband and staff were not providing appropriate supervision to
the youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4132. Grievance procedures
Section (1) An agency shall have and follow a written grievance handling
Description procedure for residents and their families. All of the following
apply:
(a) The policy shall be provided to residents, their families, and
referring sources prior to or at admission.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation HR Manager received written grievances, and the facility did not
do anything.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 6/23/2025
and did not provide additional information.
Former Youth A was interviewed over the phone on
6/27/2025. Former Youth A stated the allegation occurred when
she was placed at Vista Maria between 9/2018 – 6/2019. Former
Youth A stated there is a plastic box on each wing that contains
grievances. She stated she had written several grievances, and
the protocol was to give them to the unit manager or slide it under
the door. She stated once submitted, the unit manager is
supposed to address it with youth within three days, however, this
never happened. She stated all the issues with staff were
overlooked, and she felt that no one cared. Former Youth A stated
HR Manager was the supervisor during her placement at Vista
Maria.
Staff 6 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/8/2025.
Staff 6 reported grievances are reviewed by the Consumer Rights
Officer. Grievances are placed in the Consumer Rights Officer
mailbox to be reviewed. She is not aware of any grievances filed
by Former Youth A. Staff 6 reported HR Manager was the
program manager during 2018-2019 and all issues were
addressed during post-shift and unit meetings. During the
meetings, grievances were discussed, and they explored how the
grievances could have been prevented. Staff 6 reported HR
Manager held staff accountable for what was documented in the
grievances.
10

HR Manager was interviewed over the phone on 6/13/2025.
HR Manager stated that grievances did not go to her. In each
building, there is a consumer rights office box and that is where
grievances would be submitted to be followed up by the
Consumer Rights Officer. She stated she was a unit manager
from 2017 to the end of 2019 before transitioning to HR Manager
in 2020. She stated the consumer rights box is checked three to
four times a week. The protocol to submit grievances in the
consumer rights office box is still practiced today.
A phone call attempt was made to Former Youth’s D last
known number on 8/21/2025, however, that number is
disconnected. A MiSACWIS search did not provide additional
contact information for Former Youth D.
Documentation Reviewed:
• Former Youth A had one grievance on file. The grievance
had a “today’s date” of 1/1/2019, an incident date of what
appears to read, 12/19/2018 and a received date of
1/29/2019. The grievance included a signature from Former
Consumer Rights Officer verifying completion of follow up.
There was not a finding of violation of rights.
• Complaint Inquiry Policy:
o Rights violations. At times, a Vista Maria client may believe
a staff member has violated her rights as a client. Aside
from child abuse and neglect, sexual abuse or harassment
(as defined by the State of Michigan) a client may complain
that her rights have been violated if she didn’t receive
earned privileges, her mail was censored without
justification, or she was discriminated against on the basis
of race, religion, etc. There are three types of rights or
complaint investigations that may be conducted by the
Consumer Rights Officer.
o Consumer Rights Officer. The Consumer Rights Officer
(CRO) is responsible for investigating all rights violation
complaints and responding in a timely manner.
o Written Complaint. To resolve her issues, a client may file a
written complaint with Vista Maria’s Consumer Rights
Officer. This complaint will be written and placed in the
unit’s designated complaint box. The CRO will check each
unit’s complaint box at least once a week and will review all
complaints within 24 hours of receiving them.
o The CRO will inform the building manager of the complaint
if immediate action is necessary and will interview all
involved persons as soon as possible during normal
11

business hours. The building manager will be available and
may be present for staff interviews if needed.
o Complaint resolution. The CRO will forward a report of all
findings and necessary recommendations to the building
manager.
o Internal Investigations. In the event an incident occurs that
a staff or client may feel is a rights or policy violation, the
CRO may be requested to do an internal investigation. An
internal investigation may consist of more extensive
interviews than those involved in complaint inquiries. All
staff and/or clients involved in the specific incident will be
interviewed.
o The CRO will inform the building manager of the complaint
if immediate action is necessary and will interview all
involved persons as soon as possible during normal
business hours. The building manager will be available and
may be present for staff interviews if needed.
o Investigation resolution. The CRO will complete a full report
of findings and submit to the Director of Quality for
approval. The CRO will forward necessary
recommendations for implementing improvements to the
building manager. The feedback for recommendations form
must be accurately completed and returned to the CRO
within the required timeline. Once the feedback form is
returned to the CRO, the investigation will conclude.
o Licensing Investigations. In the event an incident occurs
that is a violation of clients rights, a direct violation of Vista
Maria policy, or an allegation of suspected abuse or
neglect, the CRO will contact the Division of Child Welfare
Licensing Consultant assigned to Vista Maria and report
the incident. A full investigation will take place involving the
CRO, the Licensing Consultant and a Child Protective
Service worker as necessary. All staff and/or clients
involved in the incident will be interviewed as deemed
necessary.
o The CRO will inform the building manager of the
investigation if immediate action is necessary and will
interview all involved persons as soon as possible. The
building manager will be available and may be present for
staff interviews if needed.
o Investigation resolution. The CRO will complete a full report
of findings and submit to the Director of Quality for
approval. Once the report is approved by the Director of
Quality, the report will be forwarded to the Executive
Administrator or designee for review as necessary. The
CRO will forward necessary recommendations for
12

implementing improvements to the building manager. The
feedback for recommendations form must be accurately
completed and returned to the CRO within the required
timeline. Once the feedback form is returned to the CRO,
the investigation will conclude. The approved report will be
returned to the CRO and the CRO will forward a copy to the
Vice President of Treatment Programs.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as there was not enough
evidence to support a rule violation. Grievances are addressed by
the consumer rights officer and there is a policy to support the
protocol. One grievance was on file from Youth A and was
addressed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158. Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Allegation 1:
Former Staff 1 hit Former Youth A in the face.
Allegation 2:
Former Staff 2 would throw youth around after restraining them.
Investigation Allegation 1:
Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 6/23/2025
and did not provide additional information.
Former Youth A was interviewed over the phone on
6/27/2025. Former Youth A stated the allegation regarding Former
Staff 1 occurred when she was placed at Vista Maria between
9/2018 – 6/2019. Former Youth A stated that on an unspecific
date, she was speaking to Former Staff 5 about an incident that
happened at school. She stated Former Staff 1 said she was lying.
Former Youth A told Former Staff 1 to leave her alone and Former
Staff 1 punched Former Youth A in the face. Former Youth A
stated she punched Former Staff 1 back and they began to
physically fight. Former Staff 5 restrained her and escorted her to
her room. Former Youth A does not believe the incident was
reported. She did not recall if other youth were around.
13

A voicemail was left for Former Staff 1 on 6/9/2025 and
6/27/2025. No return call was received.
Former Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 6/27/2025.
Former Staff 3 stated he has never witnessed or heard of Former
Staff 1 slapping Former Youth A or any youth.
Former Staff 5 was contacted on 6/27/2025 and a voicemail
message was left. No return call was received.
Staff 6 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/8/2025.
Staff 6 stated she worked with Former Staff 1 a few times as
Former Staff 1 worked the morning shift, and she worked the
afternoon shift. She has not observed or heard of Former Staff 1
hitting Former Youth A in the face or any youth.
HR Manager was interviewed over the phone on 6/13/2025.
HR Manager has no knowledge of Former Staff 1 hitting Former
Youth A in the face.
Staff 7 was interviewed over the phone on 8/22/2025. She
stated she did not recall who Former Staff 1 was.
A phone call attempt was made to Former Youth’s D last
known number on 8/21/2025, however, that number is
disconnected. A MiSACWIS search did not provide additional
contact information for Former Youth D.
Documentation Reviewed:
• There were no grievances to review related to the
allegations.
• There are three incident reports that include Former Youth
A and Former Staff 1; 1/3/2019; Former Youth A was
observed grabbing another’s youths groin area. Former
Staff 1 told Former Youth A to stop and get in line. Former
Youth A tried to grab the youth’s groin area again. Former
Staff 1 asked Former Youth A to stop the inappropriate
behavior again. Former Youth A pretended she didn’t know
what staff was talking about and requested to go back to
her building. Former Youth A went to class. 1/8/2019:
Former Youth A walked into staff office to attempt to make
a phone call. Former Youth A did not comply with a
directive. Former Staff 1 and Former Staff 5 escorted
Former Youth A to her room. Former Staff 1 was on her
14

right arm and Former Staff 5 was on her left arm during the
escort. During the escort, Former Youth A was very
aggressive, hitting and kicking Former Staff 1. Former
Youth A was secluded from 3:35pm and ended at 3:50pm.
No injuries were reported. Staff debriefed with Former
Youth A after the incident. Team Leader and Supervisor
were both notified about the incident. 3/12/2019; Former
Youth A was with several youth in the bathroom when a
marijuana joint was present in the bathroom that was found
by Former Staff 1. All youth Denied it was theirs. (None of
the reports identified who wrote/submitted the report)
• Former Staff 1 completed Professional Development
training on 3/4/2019 and CPI - Nonviolent Physical Crisis
Intervention Training on 6/11/2019.
• Staff and Client Interaction Policy:
o Corporal punishment (spanking, paddling, slapping,
pinching, twisting arms, pulling hair, etc.) of clients is
never, under any circumstances, permitted.
Allegation 2:
Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 6/23/2025
and did not provide additional information.
Former Youth A was interviewed over the phone on
6/27/2025. Former Youth A stated the allegation occurred when
she was placed at Vista Maria between 9/2018 – 6/2019. Former
Youth A stated Former Staff 2 was aggressive and would try to
hurt the youth when he restrained them. She stated he would
come to work angry every single day. She stated that when
Former Staff 2 restrained her, he put her arms behind her back in
a way that it felt like it was going to break. Former Youth A could
not fully explain the restraint in detail. Former Youth A could not
provide the exact date or whether there were witnesses. She
stated this occurred during her placement from 9/2018 – 6/2019.
Former Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 6/27/2025.
Former Staff 3 stated he has never witnessed or heard of Former
Staff 2 throwing youths around after restraining them. Former Staff
2 could not recall the name of the restraint model used at Vista
Maria, but he described the restraints used as a two person hold,
and one staff would hold a youth’s arm on one side while another
staff was on the other side doing the same thing. He stated
Former Staff 2 was never alone when restraining a youth. He
stated that Former Staff 2 was a good staff member and never

• Behavior Management Policy:
o To maintain a safe environment for all Vista Maria
clients and staff, behavior management interventions
are only used when a client presents a danger to self or
others. These interventions should only be used when
all other less restrictive behavior management
interventions (i.e., verbal de-escalation, therapeutic
interventions) have been explored.
o To prevent the need for behavior management
interventions, Vista Maria staff serve as role models to
our clients by building and maintaining a therapeutic
alliance and strengthening youth self-capacities. Vista
Maria staff will continuously provide a safe, supportive,
and nurturing environment in which each client can
learn and practice coping and de-escalation
mechanisms that work best for each individual.
o Staff Training. Vista Maria’s behavior management
policies and practices comply with federal, state, and
local legal regulatory requirements. Vista Maria shall
require staff to have ongoing education, training and
demonstrated knowledge of the following:
o Techniques to identify client’s behaviors, events, and
environmental factors that may trigger emergency
safety situations.
o Understanding a client’s history of trauma.
o The use of non-physical intervention skills, such as
verbal de-escalation, mediation conflict resolution,
active listening, and verbal and observational methods
to prevent emergency safety situations.
o The safe use of physical intervention, including the
ability to recognize and respond to signs of physical
17

distress in clients who are in physical intervention or
who are being placed in physical intervention.
o To ensure competency, Vista Maria staff are certified in
behavior management strategies as taught by a certified
instructor and receive annual training on permitted
interventions.
o Negative effects that can result from misuse of
restrictive behavior management interventions.
o Staff who receive training on behavior management
interventions are to pass a post-test and are observed
in practice. Also, staff will be trained in Trauma Informed
Care practices to aid with additional verbal de-
escalation techniques. The use of behavior
management interventions by any person other than
trained personnel is prohibited.
o De-escalation. Various de-escalation techniques may
be utilized to maintain the safety of the Former Youth
And staff in the environment. Staff must use the least
restrictive, safest, and most effective methods and
recognize that symptoms are adaptations.
o Physical Intervention. The following hands-on management
techniques may be utilized if the youth requires an
involuntary escort, is in danger of harm to self or others and
all other de-escalation techniques have failed to resolve the
imminent crisis situation.
o Physical/Safety Interventions. Physical or safety
intervention techniques will be utilized as an absolute last
resort.
o The process outlined below must be followed when a
client presents as a danger to self or others:
o The use of physical management is limited to the length
of time necessary for the youth to calm down and
restore safety (may not exceed twenty minutes).
o Unit/Program Manager Clinical and/or Psychiatrist must
approve longer time frames, as necessary.
o Two or more employees must be present before
physical interventions are performed.
o The request to initiate a physical intervention must be
communicated immediately to the Team Leader or
Supervisor on shift. The team involved will discuss and
implement the crisis intervention plan. A leader will be
present on every shift to assist with crisis to offer
support and guidance to staff involved.
o Staff are only permitted to utilize approved behavior
management techniques as taught by an approved
behavior management technique.

o Provision of food and water and use of the bathroom will
be provided as needed.
o Physical Intervention will be discontinued when a client
is no longer a danger to themselves or others and is
beginning to regain emotional control. Physical
intervention will be utilized for the minimum amount of
time necessary to maintain safety.
• Prohibited Behavior Intervention Practices
o Vista Maria strictly prohibits excessive or inappropriate
use of behavior management intervention. Behavior
management interventions will not be used as a form of
discipline or to force compliance, for the convenience of
staff, or for property damage that does not involve
threatening danger to self or others.
• Prohibited Physical Intervention Practices include but are
not to:
o Personal physical intervention shall not be imposed as a
means of coercion, discipline, convenience, or
retaliation by staff.
o Behavior management interventions by clients or
untrained staff.

waste.

blades, etc., whether contaminated or not, must be picked
up by mechanical means, e.g., tongs, broom and dust pan,
